rule.field: Web authentication failed
rule.description: Web authentication failed

rule.field: Multiple web authentication failures
rule.description: Multiple times web authentication failures
rule.info: Description: Multiple times web authentication failures occur when a user attempts to log in to a website but it unsuccessful after several tries. This can happen due to incorrect passwords, issues with the user account, or problems with the website itself. Frequent failures may lead to temporary account locks or additional security measures to protect against unauthorized access.

rule.description: Common cache error when files were removed

rule.field: Invalid URI, file name too long
rule.description: Invalid URI, file name too long

rule.field: Database authentication attempt

rule.field: Database error
rule.description: Database error

rule.field: Database fatal error
rule.description: Database fatal error

rule.field: Multiple database errors
rule.description: Multiple database errors

rule.field: Possible brute force attack detected (ATTACK T1110.001, T1110.003)
rule.description: Possible brute force attack detected (ATTACK T1110.001, T1110.003)
rule.info: Description: A possible brute force attack detected means that there have been repeated attempts to gain unauthorized access to an account or system by trying many different passwords or encryption keys in quick succession. This method relies on systematically guessing credentials until the correct one is found. Detection typically triggers security alerts to prevent potential breaches.

rule.field: Apache User Authentication Failed.
rule.description: Apache User Authentication Failed.

rule.field: Attempt to access a non-existent file.
rule.description: Attempt to access a non-existent file.

rule.field: Attempt to access forbidden directory index.
rule.description: Attempt to access forbidden directory index.

rule.field: ATTACK T1190: Apache Bash Shellshock attack attempt detected in error log.
rule.description: ATTACK T1190: Apache Bash Shellshock attack attempt detected in error log.
rule.info: Description: An Apache Bash Shellshock attack attempt detected in the error log means someone is trying to exploit a vulnerability in the Bash shell on a web server. This could allow them to run harmful commands. The error log records this suspicious activity to help protect the server.

rule.field: Attempt to authenticate a non-existent user.
rule.description: Attempt to authenticate a non-existent user.
rule.info: Description: An attempt to authenticate a non-existent user means that someone is trying to log in using a username that doesn't exist in the system. This could happen by mistake or as part of a malicious attempt to access accounts. The system recognizes that the user is not registered and typically denies access.

rule.field: Apache Segmentation Fault.
rule.description: Apache Segmentation Fault.

rule.field: ATTACK T1190: Malformed Host header.
rule.description: ATTACK T1190: Malformed Host header.

rule.field: ATTACK T1190: Invalid URI request performed.
rule.description: ATTACK T1190: Invalid URI request performed.

rule.field: Invalid Method request performed.
rule.description: Invalid Method request performed.

rule.field: HTTP request without a hostname.
rule.description: HTTP request without a hostname.

rule.field: Request contains malformed headers.
rule.description: Request contains malformed headers.

rule.field: Apache child process ended.
rule.description: Apache child process ended.

rule.field: Apache server shutting down.
rule.description: Apache server shutting down.

rule.field: Apache server configuration denied client access.
rule.description: Apache server configuration denied client access.

rule.field: Apache server running out of threads.
rule.description: Apache server running out of threads.

rule.field: Requested Page Moved Permanently.
rule.description: Requested Page Moved Permanently.

rule.field: Requested Page - Temporary Redirect.
rule.description: Requested Page - Temporary Redirect.

rule.field: Bad Request.
rule.description: Bad Request.

rule.field: Request Refused.
rule.description: Request Refused.

rule.field: Requested Page Not Found.
rule.description: Requested Page Not Found.

rule.field: Request Timeout.
rule.description: Request Timeout.

rule.field: Request URI Too Long.
rule.description: Request URI Too Long.

rule.field: Internal Server Error.
rule.description: Internal Server Error.

rule.field: Bad Gateway.
rule.description: Bad Gateway.

rule.field: Service Unavailable.
rule.description: Service Unavailable.

rule.field: Gateway Time-out.
rule.description: Gateway Time-out.

rule.field: HTTP Version Not Supported.
rule.description: HTTP Version Not Supported.

rule.field: ATTACK T1190: Apache Bash Shellshock attack attempt detected in access log.
rule.description: ATTACK T1190: Apache Bash Shellshock attack attempt detected in access log.
rule.info: Description: An Apache Bash Shellshock attack attempt detected in the access log means that someone is trying to exploit a known vulnerability in the Bash shell on a web server. This activity is recorded in the access log, which tracks all requests made to the server. Such attempts can indicate malicious intent, as attackers may be trying to execute harmful commands. The log helps administrators monitor and respond to these potential threats.

rule.field: ATTACK T1110: Multiple authentication failures from same source IP.
rule.description: ATTACK T1110: Multiple authentication failures from same source IP.
rule.info: Description: Multiple authentication failures from the same source IP means that a single IP address is trying to log in repeatedly but failing each time. This can indicate a potential security issue, such as a user forgetting their password or an attempt to gain unauthorized access. Monitoring these failures helps identify suspicious activity and protect against possible attacks.

rule.field: Multiple access attempts of a non existent file.
rule.description: Multiple access attempts of a non existent file.
rule.info: Description: Multiple access attempts of a non-existent file means that there have been repeated attempts to open or retrieve a file that doesn't exist on the server. This could be due to a user typing the wrong filename, a broken link, or a malicious attempt to find vulnerabilities. Monitoring these attempts helps detect unusual activity and maintain server security.

rule.field: ATTACK T1190: SQL injection attempt.
rule.description: ATTACK T1190: SQL injection attempt
rule.info: Description: An SQL injection attempt is a type of attack where someone tries to manipulate a website's database by inserting malicious SQL code into input fields, like login forms. This can allow the attacker to access, modify, or delete data from the database without authorization. Detecting such attempts is crucial for protecting sensitive information and maintaining the security of the website.

rule.field: ATTACK T1190: Common web attack.
rule.description: ATTACK T1190: Common web attack.
rule.info: Description: A common web attack refers to various tactics used by cybercriminals to exploit vulnerabilities in websites or web applications. These attacks can include methods like phishing (tricking users into revealing personal information), SQL injection (manipulating databases), cross-site scripting (injecting malicious scripts), and denial-of-service attacks (overloading a server to make it unavailable).

rule.field: directory travesal attack
rule.description: directory travesal attack
rule.info: Description: A directory traversal attack is a method used by attackers to access restricted files and directories on a web server by manipulating the file path in a URL. By using special characters (like "../"), they can navigate outside the intended directory and potentially access sensitive information, such as configuration files or user data.

rule.field: ATTACK T1190: ASCII control characters in URL encoding detected
rule.description: ATTACK T1190: ASCII control characters in URL encoding detected
rule.info: Description: ASCII control characters in URL encoding detected means that a URL contains characters that are not typically allowed, such as non-printable control characters. These characters can be used maliciously to manipulate how the server processes the request. Detecting them is important for identifying potential security threats and ensuring that only valid, safe URLs are processed by the server.

rule.field: ATTACK T1190: XSS (Cross Site Scripting) attempt
rule.description: ATTACK T1190: XSS (Cross Site Scripting) attempt
rule.info: Description: An XSS (Cross Site Scripting) attempt occurs when an attacker tries to inject malicious scripts into a web page that other users will view. This can allow the attacker to steal sensitive information, such as cookies or login credentials, or to perform actions on behalf of the user without their consent.

rule.field: A web attack returned code 200 (success)
rule.description: A web attack returned code 200 (success)
rule.info: Description: A web attack that returned code 200 (success) means that the malicious request was processed by the server without triggering any errors, indicating that the server executed the request successfully. This can be misleading, as a successful response doesn’t mean the request was legitimate; it may indicate that the attacker was able to access or manipulate data without detection.

rule.field: ATTACK T1190: Multiple SQL injection attempts from same source ip
rule.description: ATTACK T1190: Multiple SQL injection attempts from same source ip
rule.info: Description: Multiple SQL injection attempts from same source IP means that a specific IP address is making repeated attempts to exploit vulnerabilities in a website's database by injecting harmful SQL code. This pattern suggests a potential attack, where the attacker is trying to gain unauthorized access to data or manipulate the database.

rule.field: ATTACK T1190: Multiple common web attacks from same source ip
rule.description: ATTACK T1190: Multiple common web attacks from same source ip
rule.info: Description: Multiple common web attacks from same source IP means that a specific IP address is making repeated attempts to execute various types of attacks on a web application or server. These attacks may include methods like phishing, SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), or denial-of-service attempts. This behavior indicates a potential threat, suggesting that the attacker is targeting the system to exploit vulnerabilities.

rule.field: ATTACK T1190: Multiple directory traversal attacks from same source ip
rule.description: ATTACK T1190: Multiple directory traversal attacks from same source ip.
rule.info: Description: Multiple directory traversal attacks from same source IP means that a specific IP address is repeatedly trying to exploit vulnerabilities in a web server to access restricted files and directories. This behavior suggests an attempt to navigate outside the intended file structure, potentially exposing sensitive information.

rule.field: ATTACK T1190: Multiple XSS (Cross Site Scripting) attempts from same source ip.
rule.description: ATTACK T1190: Multiple XSS (Cross Site Scripting) attempts from same source ip.
rule.info: Description: Multiple XSS (Cross Site Scripting) attempts from same source IP means that a specific IP address is repeatedly trying to inject malicious scripts into a web application. This behavior indicates an effort to exploit vulnerabilities in the site, potentially allowing the attacker to steal sensitive data or perform unauthorized actions on behalf of users. Monitoring these attempts is crucial for enhancing security and protecting users from such threats.

rule.field: Online defragmentation started.
rule.description: Online defragmentation started.

rule.field: Online defragmentation complete.
rule.description: Online defragmentation complete.

rule.field: LDAP over SSL failed.
rule.description: LDAP over SSL failed.
rule.info: Description: An attempt to establish an LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) connection over SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) has failed. This issue may indicate problems with the server configuration, certificate validation, or network connectivity. A failed SSL connection can compromise the security of data transmission and should be investigated promptly to ensure secure access to directory services and protect sensitive information.

rule.field: Directory Service database update success.
rule.description: Directory Service database update success.

rule.field: Database engine recovery complete.
rule.description: Database engine recovery complete.

rule.field: Database engine start success.
rule.description: Database engine start success.

rule.field: Intersite transport logon failed.
rule.description: Intersite transport logon failed.

rule.field: Multiple intersite transport logon failures.
rule.description: Multiple intersite transport logon failures.
rule.info: Description: Multiple intersite transport logon failures refer to repeated unsuccessful attempts to authenticate or log in to a network service or application across different sites or domains within a distributed system. This is often seen in environments using protocols like LDAP or Kerberos for authentication.

rule.field: Local domain controller became topology generator.
rule.description: Local domain controller became topology generator.

rule.description: Active directory rebuilding quota-tracking table success.

rule.field: Bad page link has been detected.
rule.description: Bad page link has been detected.
rule.info: Description: A bad page link has been detected, potentially indicating a malicious link that may have been executed by the user. This could suggest an attempt to exploit vulnerabilities or compromise security. Immediate investigation is necessary to assess the risk and take appropriate action to protect users and the system.

rule.description: ATTACK T1021.004, T1078: Successful SSH authentication detected

rule.field: Special privileges assigned to new logon
rule.description: Special privileges assigned to new logon

rule.field: Attempt to login using a non-existent user (ATTACK T1087)
rule.description: Attempt to login using a non-existent user (ATTACK T1087)
rule.info: Description: An attempt to log in using a non-existent user account has been detected (related to ATTACK T1087). This behavior may indicate probing for valid usernames or unauthorized access attempts, potentially signaling an attack. It is crucial to investigate the source of these login attempts to mitigate the risk of credential harvesting or further exploitation of the system.

rule.field: ATTACK T1069.001: Permission Groups Discovery: Local Groups
rule.description: ATTACK T1069.001: Permission Groups Discovery: Local Groups

rule.field: ATTACK T1548.003: A successful SUDO session opened to ROOT.
rule.description: ATTACK T1548.003: A successful SUDO session opened to ROOT.
rule.info: Description: A successful SUDO session has been opened to the ROOT account (related to ATTACK T1548.003). This activity indicates elevated privileges being granted, which can pose significant security risks if exploited. It may suggest unauthorized access or misconfigured permissions.

rule.field: ATTACK T1110: Multiple Windows Logon Failures
rule.description: ATTACK T1110: Multiple Windows Logon Failures

rule.field: Attempt to login with an invalid user (ATTACK T1087)
rule.description: Attempt to login with an invalid user (ATTACK T1087)
rule.info: Description: An attempt to log in with an invalid user account has been detected (related to ATTACK T1087). This behavior may indicate unauthorized access attempts or probing for valid usernames, raising concerns about potential security breaches.

rule.field: ATTACK T1548.003: User successfully changed UID to root
rule.description: ATTACK T1548.003: User successfully changed UID to root.
Multiple Pre-authentication failures from same user in one minutes.
rule.info: Description: Multiple pre-authentication failures from the same user within a minute indicate that the user is attempting to log in repeatedly but is entering incorrect credentials. This could be a sign of user error or, in some cases, a potential security threat like a brute force attack. It’s advisable to monitor the situation and consider implementing measures like account lockout or CAPTCHA to prevent further attempts.

rule.description: Multiple times Special privileges assigned.
rule.info: Description: Multiple assignments of special privileges have been detected, which may indicate unauthorized changes to user permissions or an attempt to escalate privileges within the system. This behavior could suggest malicious activity or misconfiguration.

rule.description: Multiple times failed Windows Logon on same endpoint
rule.info: Description: Multiple failed Windows logon attempts have been detected on the same endpoint. This pattern may indicate unauthorized access attempts, such as brute-force attacks or credential guessing.

rule.description: Multiple times Windows Logon failed from same user and different endpoint.
rule.info: Description: Multiple times Windows logon failed from the same user and different endpoints indicates that one user is repeatedly trying to log in unsuccessfully from various devices. This often suggests a brute force attack, where different passwords are being tested.

rule.field: Logon Type:\s+(2)
rule.description: Multiple times Windows local Login failed
rule.info: Description: Multiple times Windows local login failed refers to a scenario where an attacker or unauthorized user repeatedly tries to access a local Windows account by entering various passwords within a short timeframe. This pattern suggests a brute force attack, where the goal is to guess the correct password through exhaustive trial and error. Such attempts can lead to account compromise if successful.

rule.field: Logon Type:\s+(3)
rule.description: Multiple times domain Login failed
rule.info: Description: Multiple times domain login failed refers to a situation where a user’s account is targeted by repeated login attempts using various passwords in a bid to gain unauthorized access. This pattern typically involves multiple failed login attempts within a short period, indicating a brute force attack. Such attacks can compromise account security and lead to unauthorized access if successful.

rule.description: Multiple times User changed UID to root
rule.info: Description: Multiple changes to the User ID (UID) to the root account have been detected. This behavior may indicate unauthorized attempts to gain elevated privileges, which can pose significant security risks.
